Notes

(VEGFA-notes.md)

VEGFA Notes - ISOFORMS Project

Key Isoform Biology

VEGFA has 17 named isoforms from alternative splicing, representing extreme diversity in isoform function.

Major Isoforms by Length

Isoform UniProt ID Length Heparin Binding Matrix Bound Key Feature
VEGF206 P15692-1 206 AA Strong Yes Longest, matrix-bound
VEGF189 P15692-2 189 AA Strong Yes Matrix-bound
VEGF165 P15692-4 165 AA Moderate Intermediate Canonical "VEGF"
VEGF121 P15692-9 121 AA None No Freely diffusible
VEGF165B P15692-8 165 AA ? ? ANTI-ANGIOGENIC

Critical Isoform Difference: VEGF165 vs VEGF165B

UniProt explicitly states for VEGF165B:

"Binds to the KDR receptor but does not activate downstream signaling pathways, does not activate angiogenesis and inhibits tumor growth" PMID:15520188

This means:
- VEGF165: Pro-angiogenic, promotes tumor growth
- VEGF165B: Anti-angiogenic, inhibits tumor growth

Same length (165 AA), same receptor binding, but opposite biological effects!

Heparin Binding and Matrix Association

The longer isoforms (VEGF189, VEGF206) contain heparin-binding domains and remain matrix-bound, creating:
- Steep gradients - important for vessel sprouting
- Localized signaling - concentrated at source

The shorter isoform (VEGF121) lacks heparin binding:
- Freely diffusible - spreads through tissue
- Broad signaling - less directional

GOA Annotation Status

  • 267 total annotations
  • NO isoform-specific annotations (no P15692-X identifiers)
  • Likely conflates pro-angiogenic (most isoforms) with anti-angiogenic (VEGF165B) functions

Expected Annotation Issues

  1. Angiogenesis annotations - should specify which isoforms
  2. "Positive regulation of angiogenesis" - NOT true for VEGF165B
  3. VEGFR binding - all isoforms bind, but different downstream effects

Key References

  • PMID:15520188 - VEGF165B anti-angiogenic properties
  • Original VEGF papers describing isoform differences

üìÑ View Raw YAML

 
id: P15692
gene_symbol: VEGFA
product_type: PROTEIN
status: INITIALIZED
taxon:
  id: NCBITaxon:9606
  label: Homo sapiens
description: 'VEGFA (Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor A) is the master regulator
  of angiogenesis. CRITICAL ISOFORM BIOLOGY: Alternative splicing produces 17 isoforms
  with diverse functions: (1) Most isoforms (VEGF121/165/189/206) are PRO-ANGIOGENIC,
  differing in heparin binding and matrix association - VEGF121 is freely diffusible
  while VEGF189/206 are matrix-bound; (2) VEGF165B (P15692-8) is ANTI-ANGIOGENIC -
  it binds VEGFR2 but does NOT activate downstream signaling and INHIBITS tumor growth
  [PMID:15520188]. All current GOA annotations are for positive angiogenesis regulation
  - MISSING the anti-angiogenic VEGF165B function. This is a case where isoforms have
  qualitatively different (even opposite) biological effects.'
existing_annotations:
  - term:
      id: GO:0005172
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor binding
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA binds to both VEGFR1 (FLT1) and VEGFR2 (KDR) receptors. 
        This is a core molecular function shared by all VEGFA isoforms including
        VEGF121, VEGF165, VEGF189, VEGF206, and VEGF165B. The UniProt entry 
        explicitly states binding to FLT1/VEGFR1 and KDR/VEGFR2 receptors. 
        Importantly, even the anti-angiogenic VEGF165B isoform binds to 
        KDR/VEGFR2, though it does not activate downstream signaling. The deep 
        research confirms VEGFA binds to VEGFR1 with approximately 50-fold 
        higher affinity than VEGFR2 [VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md].
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function of VEGFA. All isoforms bind VEGF 
        receptors, making this annotation universally applicable to the gene 
        product. Well-supported by IBA phylogenetic inference and extensive 
        experimental literature.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:7929439
          supporting_text: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a 
            homodimeric peptide growth factor which binds to two structurally 
            related tyrosine kinase receptors denoted Flt1 and KDR.
        - reference_id: file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
          supporting_text: 'provider: perplexity'
  - term:
      id: GO:0008083
      label: growth factor activity
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA is a canonical growth factor that stimulates endothelial 
        cell proliferation through VEGFR2 signaling. The deep research confirms 
        VEGFA stimulates multiple cellular responses including proliferation, 
        survival, and migration. VEGF165 induces approximately 27% increase in 
        HUVEC proliferation. However, this is true for pro-angiogenic isoforms 
        (VEGF121/165/189/206) but NOT for VEGF165B which lacks mitogenic 
        activity.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. Growth factor activity is well-documented
        for the major pro-angiogenic isoforms. The IBA inference is 
        phylogenetically sound.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:21771332
          supporting_text: VEGF stimulated HUVEC proliferation by 27% relative 
            to untreated cells
  - term:
      id: GO:0048010
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor signaling pathway
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA is the canonical ligand that activates VEGF receptor 
        signaling pathways through VEGFR1 and VEGFR2. Binding induces receptor 
        dimerization and autophosphorylation, activating downstream 
        PLCgamma-PKC-MAPK, PI3K-Akt, and p38 MAPK pathways. VEGF165B also binds 
        receptors but initiates only weak signaling insufficient for angiogenic 
        responses [VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md].
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. VEGFA is the defining ligand for VEGFR 
        signaling pathways. All isoforms engage receptors, though with different
        downstream consequences.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:7929439
          supporting_text: The KDR expressing cells showed striking changes in 
            cell morphology, actin reorganization and membrane ruffling, 
            chemotaxis and mitogenicity upon VEGF stimulation
  - term:
      id: GO:0005615
      label: extracellular space
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: 'VEGFA is a secreted growth factor that functions in the extracellular
        space. It contains an N-terminal signal sequence targeting it to the secretory
        pathway. However, isoform localization varies: VEGF121 is freely diffusible,
        VEGF165 has intermediate bioavailability, while VEGF189/206 are matrix-bound.
        Substantial intracrine functions have also been documented [VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md].'
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core cellular component for the secreted protein. While some 
        intracrine signaling exists, the primary function is as an extracellular
        signaling molecule.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0038084
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor signaling pathway
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: This is essentially the same as GO:0048010 (vascular endothelial 
        growth factor receptor signaling pathway). VEGFA is the canonical ligand
        initiating VEGF signaling through VEGFR1/2 receptors. Both 
        pro-angiogenic and anti-angiogenic isoforms participate in this pathway,
        though with different outcomes.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. VEGFA is the defining ligand of the VEGF 
        signaling pathway. Note this term (GO:0038084) is a child of GO:0048010.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20660291
          supporting_text: gremlin binds VEGF receptor-2 (VEGFR2), the main 
            transducer of VEGF-mediated angiogenic signals
  - term:
      id: GO:0042056
      label: chemoattractant activity
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA functions as a chemoattractant for endothelial cells, 
        promoting their directed migration during angiogenesis. It also serves 
        as a chemoattractant for monocytes and macrophages via VEGFR1. The deep 
        research notes VEGF acts as a chemoattractant for endothelial cells and 
        inflammatory cells including macrophages.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. Chemoattractant activity is essential for
        VEGFA's role in angiogenesis and inflammation.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:7929439
          supporting_text: The KDR expressing cells showed striking changes in 
            cell morphology, actin reorganization and membrane ruffling, 
            chemotaxis and mitogenicity upon VEGF stimulation
  - term:
      id: GO:0050930
      label: induction of positive chemotaxis
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA induces positive chemotaxis of endothelial cells towards 
        the VEGF source, essential for directed vessel sprouting during 
        angiogenesis. This is mediated primarily through VEGFR2 signaling and 
        downstream Rac1/Cdc42 activation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. Chemotactic guidance of endothelial cells
        is essential for VEGFA's angiogenic function.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:7929439
          supporting_text: The KDR expressing cells showed striking changes in 
            cell morphology, actin reorganization and membrane ruffling, 
            chemotaxis and mitogenicity upon VEGF stimulation
  - term:
      id: GO:0060754
      label: positive regulation of mast cell chemotaxis
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA can regulate mast cell chemotaxis through VEGFR1 and VEGFR2
        expressed on mast cells. This is a peripheral function related to 
        VEGFA's broader roles in inflammation and immune modulation rather than 
        a core angiogenic function.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: While VEGFA does regulate immune cell chemotaxis, mast cell 
        chemotaxis is not a core function. This represents a pleiotropic effect 
        in inflammatory contexts.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0002040
      label: sprouting angiogenesis
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: 'VEGFA is the master regulator of sprouting angiogenesis. It promotes
        tip cell selection, endothelial cell migration, proliferation, and vessel
        lumen formation. CRITICAL ISOFORM NOTE: This applies to pro-angiogenic isoforms
        (VEGF121/165/189/206) but NOT to VEGF165B, which is anti-angiogenic and inhibits
        sprouting.'
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core function for the majority of VEGFA isoforms. While VEGF165B 
        inhibits angiogenesis, the predominant isoforms are pro-angiogenic. The 
        IBA annotation captures the conserved ancestral function. 
        Isoform-specific annotation would require GO annotation extensions.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0001666
      label: response to hypoxia
    evidence_type: IBA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000033
    review:
      summary: VEGFA expression is strongly induced by hypoxia through 
        HIF-1alpha stabilization. This is a key regulatory mechanism ensuring 
        VEGFA is produced when tissues need increased vascularization. The 
        protein itself also has structural adaptations (cystine-knot) enabling 
        proper folding under hypoxic conditions.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core regulatory relationship. Hypoxia-induced VEGFA expression is 
        one of the most well-characterized gene regulatory responses in 
        mammalian biology.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md

        correctly captures the core function. ISOFORM NOTE: Pro-angiogenic isoforms
        (VEGF121/165/189/206) promote angiogenesis; VEGF165B is anti-angiogenic.'
      action: ACCEPT

        informative.

      id: GO:0005634
      label: nucleus
    evidence_type: IEA

    review:
      summary: Nuclear-localized VEGF has been detected in multiple cell types 
        as part of intracrine signaling. The deep research notes nuclear VEGF 
        and VEGFR2 participate in direct regulation of gene expression and 
        metabolic homeostasis.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: While nuclear VEGFA exists and has functional significance for 
        intracrine signaling, the primary localization and function is 
        extracellular. Nuclear localization represents a secondary function.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md

        secretion. Intracrine VEGF signaling also involves cytoplasmic pools of 
        VEGF and its receptors.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Cytoplasmic localization is a transit compartment during 
        biosynthesis. The functional localization is extracellular. This is 
        accurate but not a core functional location.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0005783
      label: endoplasmic reticulum
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000044
    review:
      summary: VEGFA undergoes dimerization and disulfide bond formation in the 
        ER during biosynthesis. The deep research notes that VEGFA can 
        efficiently complete disulfide bond formation in the ER even under 
        hypoxia.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: ER is a transit compartment during biosynthesis, not a functional 
        location. Accurate but represents biosynthetic pathway rather than 
        functional localization.
      additional_reference_ids:

  - term:
      id: GO:0005794
      label: Golgi apparatus
    evidence_type: IEA

    review:
      summary: VEGFA transits through the Golgi for N-linked glycosylation 
        during secretion. Post-Golgi transport depends on glycosylation 
        modifications.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Golgi is a transit compartment for secretion, not a functional 
        location. Accurate but represents biosynthetic pathway.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0008083
      label: growth factor activity
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000120
    review:
      summary: VEGFA is a canonical growth factor stimulating endothelial cell 
        proliferation and survival. This IEA annotation is consistent with the 
        IBA annotation and extensive experimental evidence.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. Duplicates IBA annotation but IEA 
        provides independent computational evidence support.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0008201
      label: heparin binding
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000120
    review:
      summary: Heparin binding is ISOFORM-SPECIFIC. VEGF121 lacks heparin 
        binding (no exons 6/7). VEGF165 has intermediate heparin affinity (exon 
        7 only). VEGF189/206 have high heparin affinity (exons 6 and 7). This is
        a key determinant of bioavailability.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Important molecular function, though isoform-specific. The 
        predominant isoforms (VEGF165, VEGF189) do bind heparin. Annotation is 
        valid at gene level.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0008284
      label: positive regulation of cell population proliferation
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000117
    review:
      summary: 'VEGFA stimulates endothelial cell proliferation through VEGFR2-PLCgamma-PKC-MAPK
        signaling. Also promotes proliferation of other cell types. ISOFORM NOTE:
        VEGF165B does not stimulate proliferation.'
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process for pro-angiogenic isoforms. Proliferation
        is essential for angiogenesis. The term is appropriately general.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0016020
      label: membrane
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000002
    review:
      summary: VEGFA associates with the plasma membrane surface before 
        shedding. The deep research notes substantial fraction localizes to 
        outer plasma membrane in punctate pattern.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Membrane association is transient during secretion. Primary 
        function is extracellular. This InterPro-based annotation is less 
        informative than specific localization terms.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0030154
      label: cell differentiation
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000043
    review:
      summary: VEGFA promotes endothelial cell differentiation during vascular 
        development and angiogenesis. However, this term is very broad.
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: While VEGFA affects endothelial cell differentiation, the term is 
        too general. More specific terms like vasculogenesis or endothelial cell
        differentiation would be more informative.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0042056
      label: chemoattractant activity
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000117
    review:
      summary: VEGFA is a chemoattractant for endothelial cells and 
        monocytes/macrophages. This IEA annotation is consistent with the IBA 
        annotation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. Duplicates IBA but IEA provides 
        independent evidence support.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0043117
      label: positive regulation of vascular permeability
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000117
    review:
      summary: 'VEGFA (originally called Vascular Permeability Factor/VPF) is a potent
        inducer of vascular permeability through phosphorylation of junctional proteins
        and Rac1-mediated cytoskeletal changes. ISOFORM NOTE: Pro-angiogenic isoforms
        only.'
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. VEGFA was originally identified as a 
        permeability factor. This is a defining function of the protein.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0043184
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 binding
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000117
    review:
      summary: VEGFA binds VEGFR2/KDR, the main transducer of angiogenic 
        signals. All isoforms including VEGF165B bind VEGFR2, though with 
        different signaling outcomes.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. VEGFR2 binding is essential for VEGFA 
        signaling.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:7929439
          supporting_text: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a 
            homodimeric peptide growth factor which binds to two structurally 
            related tyrosine kinase receptors denoted Flt1 and KDR.
  - term:
      id: GO:0045766
      label: positive regulation of angiogenesis
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000117
    review:
      summary: 'VEGFA is the master positive regulator of angiogenesis. CRITICAL ISOFORM
        NOTE: This applies to pro-angiogenic isoforms (VEGF121/165/189/206) but NOT
        to VEGF165B, which INHIBITS angiogenesis and should have a negative regulation
        annotation.'
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core function for pro-angiogenic isoforms. The annotation 
        correctly captures the predominant function. A separate annotation for 
        VEGF165B anti-angiogenic activity would be needed for completeness.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0048010
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor signaling pathway

    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000117

      reason: Core biological process. Duplicates IBA but provides independent

        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0051781
      label: positive regulation of cell division
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000043
    review:
      summary: VEGFA promotes endothelial cell division through MAPK signaling. 
        This is related to its proliferative effects.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Valid biological process annotation. Cell division is required for
        angiogenesis.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0005515
      label: protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:10543948
    review:
      summary: Generic protein binding annotation. VEGFA binds multiple proteins
        including receptors (VEGFR1, VEGFR2, NRP1), matrix components, and 
        coreceptors.
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: Protein binding is too generic. More specific binding terms (VEGFR
        binding, heparin binding) are more informative. This is a common 
        over-annotation pattern.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:10543948
          supporting_text: 'Solution structure of the VEGF-binding domain of Flt-1:
            comparison of its free and bound states.'
  - term:
      id: GO:0005515
      label: protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:16763549
    review:
      summary: Generic protein binding annotation based on neuropilin-1 and 
        VEGFR2 interaction studies.
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: Protein binding is too generic. The specific interaction partners 
        (NRP1, VEGFR2) warrant more specific GO terms.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:16763549
          supporting_text: Jun 8. Glycosaminoglycan modification of neuropilin-1
            modulates VEGFR2 signaling.
  - term:

    original_reference_id: PMID:17222790
    review:

      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: Protein binding is too generic. Neuropilin binding would be more 
        informative.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:17222790
          supporting_text: Blocking neuropilin-1 function has an additive effect
            with anti-VEGF to inhibit tumor growth.

  - term:
      id: GO:0042802
      label: identical protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:12207021
    review:
      summary: VEGFA forms homodimers stabilized by interchain disulfide bonds 
        between Cys51 and Cys60. Dimerization is essential for receptor 
        activation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. VEGFA homodimerization is required for 
        biological activity. This is more specific and informative than generic 
        protein binding.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:12207021
          supporting_text: 2002 Aug 30. The cystine knot promotes folding and 
            not thermodynamic stability in vascular endothelial growth factor.
  - term:
      id: GO:0042802
      label: identical protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:25132001
    review:
      summary: VEGFA homodimerization study. Consistent with the essential role 
        of dimerization in VEGFA function.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. Homodimerization is essential for VEGFA 
        activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:25132001
          supporting_text: Development of a highly-potent anti-angiogenic 
            VEGF8-109 heterodimer by directed blocking of its VEGFR-2 binding 
            site.

  - term:
      id: GO:0010719
      label: negative regulation of epithelial to mesenchymal transition
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000107
    review:
      summary: IEA transferred from Ensembl ortholog. The role of VEGFA in EMT 
        is complex and context-dependent. In some contexts VEGFA may inhibit EMT
        but this is not a well-established core function.
      action: UNDECIDED
      reason: EMT regulation by VEGFA is complex. This ortholog-transferred 
        annotation may not reflect human VEGFA function. Requires literature 
        review.
  - term:
      id: GO:0031290
      label: retinal ganglion cell axon guidance
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000107
    review:
      summary: VEGFA has documented roles in neural guidance including retinal 
        development. This is a pleiotropic developmental function beyond core 
        angiogenesis.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: VEGFA has neural guidance functions but this is peripheral to its 
        core angiogenic role. Valid developmental function.
      additional_reference_ids:

  - term:
      id: GO:0035924
      label: cellular response to vascular endothelial growth factor stimulus
    evidence_type: IEA
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000107
    review:
      summary: Circular annotation - VEGFA is the stimulus, not the responder. 
        This annotation would be appropriate for VEGF receptors, not VEGFA 
        itself.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Inappropriate annotation. VEGFA is the ligand that causes the 
        stimulus, not a gene product that responds to VEGF stimulus.

  - term:
      id: GO:0031093
      label: platelet alpha granule lumen
    evidence_type: TAS
    original_reference_id: Reactome:R-HSA-481007
    review:
      summary: VEGFA is stored in platelet alpha granules and released during 
        platelet degranulation. This contributes to wound healing and vascular 
        repair.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Valid cellular component. Platelet storage is a documented 
        function.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
  - term:
      id: GO:0038084
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor signaling pathway
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20660291
    review:
      summary: Experimental study demonstrating VEGFA activates VEGFR2 
        signaling. The paper identifies gremlin as a novel VEGFR2 agonist 
        distinct from VEGF family ligands, validating VEGFA as the canonical 
        VEGFR2 ligand.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. IDA evidence from direct experimental 
        demonstration.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20660291
          supporting_text: gremlin binds VEGF receptor-2 (VEGFR2), the main 
            transducer of VEGF-mediated angiogenic signals
  - term:
      id: GO:0001525
      label: angiogenesis
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:21771332
    review:
      summary: Study comparing VEGF and leptin effects on endothelial cells. 
        VEGF (50 ng/mL) stimulated HUVEC proliferation by 27% and tube formation
        by ~60%. This directly demonstrates VEGFA angiogenic activity.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process with direct experimental evidence.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:21771332
          supporting_text: VEGF stimulated HUVEC proliferation by 27% relative 
            to untreated cells
  - term:
      id: GO:0001569
      label: branching involved in blood vessel morphogenesis
    evidence_type: IMP
    original_reference_id: PMID:23688497
    review:
      summary: IMP evidence for VEGFA role in blood vessel branching 
        morphogenesis. Publication not in cache - based on annotation appears to
        demonstrate VEGFA involvement in vessel branching.
      action: UNDECIDED
      reason: Publication PMID:23688497 not available for verification. Blood 
        vessel branching is consistent with known VEGFA functions.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:23688497
          supporting_text: Epub 2013 May 17. MicroRNA-15b contributes to 
            ginsenoside-Rg1-induced angiogenesis through increased expression of
            VEGFR-2.
  - term:
      id: GO:0001938
      label: positive regulation of endothelial cell proliferation
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:31915155
    review:
      summary: IDA evidence for VEGFA stimulating endothelial cell 
        proliferation. Function is well-established from multiple other sources.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core function. Function is well-established from multiple IDA and 
        IBA sources; additional IDA evidence is consistent.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:31915155
          supporting_text: PI3KŒ¥ as a Novel Therapeutic Target in Pathological 
            Angiogenesis.

      label: positive regulation of endothelial cell chemotaxis by

    original_reference_id: PMID:31915155

      summary: Very specific GO term capturing VEGFA-induced endothelial 
        chemotaxis via VEGFR signaling. This is consistent with established 
        VEGFA function.
      action: UNDECIDED
      reason: Publication PMID:31915155 not available for verification. Function
        is consistent with known biology but specific evidence cannot be 
        confirmed.

          supporting_text: PI3KŒ¥ as a Novel Therapeutic Target in Pathological

  - term:
      id: GO:0043066
      label: negative regulation of apoptotic process
    evidence_type: IMP
    original_reference_id: PMID:11461089
    review:
      summary: IMP evidence for VEGFA anti-apoptotic function. VEGFA promotes 
        endothelial cell survival through PI3K-Akt signaling pathway.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core function. Anti-apoptotic function is well-established from 
        deep research documenting Akt-mediated survival signaling. Consistent 
        with other IMP evidence.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:11461089
          supporting_text: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) upregulates
            BCL-2 and inhibits apoptosis in human and murine mammary 
            adenocarcinoma cells.

  - term:
      id: GO:0038084
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor signaling pathway
    evidence_type: IMP
    original_reference_id: PMID:19148554

        established from multiple sources.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. VEGFA is the canonical ligand for VEGF

      supported_by:

          supporting_text: Angiopoietin-1 reduces vascular endothelial growth 
            factor-induced brain endothelial permeability via upregulation of 
            ZO-2.
  - term:
      id: GO:0007200
      label: phospholipase C-activating G protein-coupled receptor signaling 
        pathway
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:18059339
    review:
      summary: VEGFA activates PLCgamma through VEGFR2 signaling. The study 
        shows VEGF signals through PKC pathway to activate transcription factor 
        Egr3.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core signaling mechanism. VEGFR2-PLCgamma-PKC is a major VEGFA 
        signaling pathway.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:18059339
          supporting_text: VEGF induced a rapid increase in Egr-dependent 
            transcriptional activation mediated via its major signalling 
            receptor, VEGFR2/KDR, and the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway
  - term:
      id: GO:0042056
      label: chemoattractant activity
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:18059339
    review:
      summary: VEGFA promotes endothelial cell migration. The study demonstrates
        VEGF mediates endothelial cell migration and tubulogenesis through Egr3.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core molecular function. Direct experimental evidence for 
        chemoattractant activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:18059339
          supporting_text: Inhibition of Egr3 gene expression by RNA 
            interference was effective in inhibiting basal and VEGF-induced Egr3
            gene expression, and it also inhibited VEGF-mediated endothelial 
            cell proliferation, migration and tubulogenesis
  - term:
      id: GO:0048010
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor signaling pathway
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:18059339
    review:
      summary: Direct evidence that VEGF signals through VEGFR2/KDR to activate 
        PKC pathway.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process with direct experimental evidence.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:18059339
          supporting_text: VEGF induced a rapid increase in Egr-dependent 
            transcriptional activation mediated via its major signalling 
            receptor, VEGFR2/KDR, and the protein kinase C (PKC) pathway
  - term:
      id: GO:0035767
      label: endothelial cell chemotaxis
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:18440775
    review:
      summary: Study shows VEGF induces endothelial cell migration through 
        PKD-HSP27 pathway. Knockdown of HSP27 and PKDs markedly inhibited 
        VEGF-induced HUVEC migration.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process with direct experimental evidence for 
        chemotaxis mechanism.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:18440775
          supporting_text: Knockdown of HSP27 and PKDs markedly inhibited 
            VEGF-induced HUVEC migration and tubulogenesis

    original_reference_id: PMID:18440775
    review:

        demonstrates VEGF-induced PKD activation leads to downstream signaling

    original_reference_id: PMID:18440775

        via PKD-HSP27 pathway. CRITICAL ISOFORM NOTE: Applies to pro-angiogenic isoforms
        only; VEGF165B is anti-angiogenic.'

      reason: Core biological process for pro-angiogenic isoforms.

  - term:
      id: GO:0035924
      label: cellular response to vascular endothelial growth factor stimulus
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20497126
    review:
      summary: Circular annotation - VEGFA is the stimulus, not the responder. 
        This annotation would be appropriate for VEGF receptors or downstream 
        effectors, not VEGFA itself.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Inappropriate annotation. VEGFA is the ligand that causes the 
        stimulus, not a gene product that responds to VEGF stimulus.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20497126
          supporting_text: Characterization of the biological effects of a novel
            protein kinase D inhibitor in endothelial cells.

      reason: Protein binding is too generic. More specific binding terms are 
        more informative.

  - term:
      id: GO:0035924
      label: cellular response to vascular endothelial growth factor stimulus
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:18440775
    review:
      summary: Circular annotation - VEGFA IS the stimulus, not the responder. 
        This annotation is logically problematic.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Circular annotation. VEGFA is the stimulus, not a gene responding 
        to VEGF stimulus. This annotation should be on VEGF-responsive genes, 
        not VEGFA itself.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:18440775
          supporting_text: 2008 Mar 18. Vascular endothelial growth factor 
            induces heat shock protein (HSP) 27 serine 82 phosphorylation and 
            endothelial tubulogenesis via protein kinase D and independent of 
            p38 kinase.

        Deep research notes VEGFR2 null mice die at E8.5.

      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Pleiotropic developmental process. Deep research notes lung 
        defects in VEGF120/120 mice.
  - term:
      id: GO:0030855
      label: epithelial cell differentiation
    evidence_type: ISS
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000024
    review:
      summary: VEGFA may affect epithelial differentiation through paracrine 
        effects.
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: Indirect effect. VEGFA primarily acts on endothelial cells; 
        effects on epithelium are likely secondary/paracrine.

    evidence_type: ISS
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000024

        is primary pathway.
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: VEGF-C and VEGFR3 are the primary lymphangiogenic factors. VEGFA 
        role in lymphangiogenesis is minor compared to its role in blood vessel 
        angiogenesis.

      action: ACCEPT

        documents isoform-specific heparin binding.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:14570917
          supporting_text: '2003 Oct 21. pH regulates vascular endothelial growth
            factor binding to fibronectin: a mechanism for control of extracellular
            matrix storage and release.'

      id: GO:0008284

      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core function. PMID:7929439 demonstrates mitogenic activity in 
        KDR-expressing cells.

            cell morphology, actin reorganization and membrane ruffling,

        function is angiogenic.

      id: GO:0043066
      label: negative regulation of apoptotic process
    evidence_type: IMP
    original_reference_id: PMID:10066377
    review:

        pathway.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core function for endothelial cell survival. Deep research 
        documents Akt-mediated anti-apoptotic signaling.

          supporting_text: VEGF prevents apoptosis of human microvascular 
            endothelial cells via opposing effects on MAPK/ERK and SAPK/JNK

      id: GO:0050930
      label: induction of positive chemotaxis
    evidence_type: NAS
    original_reference_id: PMID:12744932
    review:
      summary: NAS evidence for chemotaxis. Consistent with IBA and other 
        evidence.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Core biological process. VEGFA induces chemotaxis in multiple cell
        types.

          supporting_text: Vascular endothelial growth factor is a 
            chemoattractant for trophoblast cells.
  - term:
      id: GO:0016525
      label: negative regulation of angiogenesis
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
    review:
      summary: 'CRITICAL: The VEGF165B isoform (P15692-8) is ANTI-ANGIOGENIC. It binds
        VEGFR2 but fails to activate downstream signaling, acting as an endogenous
        inhibitor of angiogenesis. VEGF165B inhibits VEGF165-induced proliferation,
        migration, and vasodilatation. In colon carcinoma, VEGF165B inhibits tumor
        growth by blocking angiogenesis. This function is NOT captured by any existing
        GOA annotation.'
      action: NEW
      reason: Critical missing annotation. VEGF165B has opposite biological 
        activity to other isoforms. The deep research documents that VEGF165B 
        has anti-angiogenic properties and inhibits tumor growth. This 
        represents a fundamentally different function from the pro-angiogenic 
        isoforms currently annotated.
      additional_reference_ids:
        - file:human/VEGFA/VEGFA-deep-research-perplexity.md
core_functions:
  - molecular_function:
      id: GO:0005172
      label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor binding
    description: VEGFA binds to VEGFR1 (FLT1), VEGFR2 (KDR), and co-receptors 
      including neuropilins. This is the primary molecular function enabling all
      downstream signaling. All isoforms bind receptors, though VEGF165B binding
      does not activate signaling.
    directly_involved_in:
      - id: GO:0048010
        label: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor signaling pathway
      - id: GO:0045766
        label: positive regulation of angiogenesis
    locations:
      - id: GO:0005615
        label: extracellular space
    supported_by:
      - reference_id: PMID:7929439
        supporting_text: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a 
          homodimeric peptide growth factor which binds to two structurally 
          related tyrosine kinase receptors denoted Flt1 and KDR.
  - molecular_function:
      id: GO:0008083
      label: growth factor activity
    description: 'VEGFA is a canonical growth factor stimulating endothelial cell
      proliferation through VEGFR2-PLCgamma-PKC-MAPK signaling. ISOFORM NOTE: Pro-angiogenic
      isoforms only; VEGF165B lacks mitogenic activity.'
    directly_involved_in:
      - id: GO:0008284
        label: positive regulation of cell population proliferation
      - id: GO:0001525
        label: angiogenesis
    locations:
      - id: GO:0005615
        label: extracellular space
    supported_by:
      - reference_id: PMID:21771332
        supporting_text: VEGF caused a significant increase in proliferation by 
          27%
  - molecular_function:
      id: GO:0042056
      label: chemoattractant activity
    description: VEGFA is a chemoattractant for endothelial cells (directing 
      sprouting angiogenesis) and for monocytes/macrophages (via VEGFR1). 
      Essential for guided vessel growth and inflammatory cell recruitment.
    directly_involved_in:
      - id: GO:0001525
        label: angiogenesis
      - id: GO:0030335
        label: positive regulation of cell migration
    locations:
      - id: GO:0005615
        label: extracellular space
    supported_by:
      - reference_id: PMID:7929439
        supporting_text: The KDR expressing cells showed striking changes in 
          cell morphology, actin reorganization and membrane ruffling, 
          chemotaxis and mitogenicity upon VEGF stimulation

alternative_products:
  - name: L-VEGF189
    id: P15692-13
    description: >-
      Long form with extended N-terminus. Has intracellular functions in addition
      to secreted
      VEGF activities. The L-VEGF forms may have distinct nuclear/intracellular signaling
      roles.
  - name: VEGF206
    id: P15692-1
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061898
    description: >-
      The longest secreted isoform (206 AA). Strongly heparin-binding and matrix-bound.
      Produces dense, localized vascular sprouting patterns. Less diffusible than
      shorter isoforms.
  - name: VEGF189
    id: P15692-2
    sequence_note: VSP_061891
    description: >-
      A strongly heparin-binding, matrix-bound isoform (189 AA). Sequestered in extracellular
      matrix and released by proteases. Produces localized angiogenic effects. Important
      for
      establishing vascular patterning gradients.
  - name: VEGF183
    id: P15692-3
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061897
    description: >-
      An intermediate heparin-binding isoform. Properties intermediate between VEGF165
      and
      VEGF189.
  - name: VEGF165 (VEGF)
    id: P15692-4
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061894
    description: >-
      The predominant and best-characterized isoform (165 AA). Intermediate heparin
      binding
      and diffusibility. Binds both VEGFR1/VEGFR2 and neuropilin-1 (NRP1) coreceptor.
      This is
      the canonical pro-angiogenic isoform that most GO annotations refer to. Target
      of
      anti-VEGF therapies (bevacizumab).
  - name: VEGF148
    id: P15692-5
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061894, VSP_061901,
    description: >-
      A less common isoform with intermediate properties. Functional role less well
      characterized
      than VEGF165.
  - name: VEGF145
    id: P15692-6
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061899, VSP_061900
    description: >-
      An isoform with heparin-binding properties. Binds VEGFR2 but not neuropilins.
      Found in
      reproductive tissues and some tumors.
  - name: VEGF165B
    id: P15692-8
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061894, VSP_061903
    description: >-
      CRITICAL: An ANTI-angiogenic isoform! Uses distal splice site in exon 8 (exon
      8b) producing
      an alternative C-terminus. Binds VEGFR2 but does NOT activate downstream signaling
      for
      angiogenesis. Acts as endogenous inhibitor of pro-angiogenic VEGF isoforms.
      Downregulated
      in cancer, upregulated in quiescent vasculature. GO annotations for "positive
      regulation
      of angiogenesis" do NOT apply to this isoform - it has the OPPOSITE function.
  - name: VEGF121
    id: P15692-9
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061895, VSP_061896
    description: >-
      The shortest secreted isoform (121 AA). Freely diffusible, lacks heparin-binding
      domain.
      Does not bind neuropilins. Produces diffuse vascular networks. Important for
      long-range
      angiogenic signaling.
  - name: VEGF111
    id: P15692-10
    sequence_note: VSP_061891, VSP_061892, VSP_061893
    description: >-
      A short isoform generated by alternative splicing. Less well characterized than
      VEGF121
      and VEGF165.
  - name: L-VEGF165
    id: P15692-11
    sequence_note: VSP_061894
    description: >-
      Long form of VEGF165 with extended N-terminus. May have intracellular functions
      in
      addition to secreted activities.
  - name: L-VEGF121
    id: P15692-12
    sequence_note: VSP_061895, VSP_061896
    description: >-
      Long form of VEGF121 with extended N-terminus. May have intracellular functions.
  - name: L-VEGF206
    id: P15692-14
    sequence_note: VSP_061898
    description: >-
      Long form of VEGF206 with extended N-terminus. May have intracellular functions.
  - name: '15'
    id: P15692-15
    sequence_note: VSP_061894, VSP_061903
    description: >-
      A less characterized isoform. May have anti-angiogenic properties based on exon
      8b usage.
  - name: '16'
    id: P15692-16
    sequence_note: VSP_061897
    description: >-
      A less characterized isoform. Functional role not well established.
  - name: '17'
    id: P15692-17
    sequence_note: VSP_061894, VSP_061901, VSP_061902
    description: >-
      A less characterized isoform. Functional role not well established.
  - name: '18'
    id: P15692-18
    sequence_note: VSP_061892, VSP_061893
    description: >-
      A less characterized isoform. Functional role not well established.
